item.title: reinventing the wheel
item.description:
Always trust your curiousity.

Giles Bowkett

item.title: Core values
item.description:
If you don’t actively fight for simplicity in software, complexity will win, and it will suck.

Henrik Jorgeteg

item.title: "Hating Java in 2014"
item.description:
If your project isn't big enough to account for time to make sure you are linking to exactly the libraries, versions, etc... that you need, it's not right for Java.

(comments)

item.title: Fortune favors the bold
item.description: Scott Meyers, The Last Thing D Needs, DConf 2014, Menlo Park, California

item.title: "There is no shelf."
item.description:
I want to argue that even the ontological ideal is a mistake. Even using theoretical perfection as a measure of practical success leads to misapplication of resources.

Clay Shirky, Ontology is Overrated

item.title: That's a big Twinkie.
item.description:
Looking at the dependency graph for, say, the rails package will make your eyes bleed. I tried it here, and GraphViz needed a PNG image with 7653×10003 pixels to draw it.

Antonio Terceiro

item.title: Craft
item.description:
Always look beyond and above yourself. Always try to improve yourself. Always strive to elevate your craft.

Yoshikazu Ono, Jiro Dreams of Sushi

item.title: Standards
item.description:
In Europe, there's a standard for everything. They once standardized cucumbers

Alex Tatumizer

item.title: Concurrency is everyone's problem
item.description:
It is the modern programming problem. Nothing is more important.

(comments)

item.title: Compromise
item.description:
duplication is far cheaper than the wrong abstraction

Sandi Metz, All the Little Things, Ruby on Ales 2014, Bend, Oregon

(slides)

item.title: "The Rise and Fall of Personal Computing"
item.description:
Sometimes extremism is a better point of view than conservatism.

Horace Dediu, via Allen Wirfs-Brock

item.title: Overheard [4]
item.description: https://github.com/ericf/yui3-gallery/pull/21

item.title: Insight
item.description:
the lack of attention span that makes our eyes glaze over when we read swaths of procedural code looking for the one thing we actually care about is the same thing that prevents us from tolerating long-form exposition of approaches to help us deal with the problem.

Ernie Miller

item.title: "X rating"
item.description:
Any effort spent describing what methods to use on what URIs of interest should be entirely defined within the scope of the processing rules for a media type

Roy Fielding

item.title: Boundaries
item.description:
I’ve got a real problem with formal education in today’s world, and I’m sad to say that when it does matter, it’s about the piece of paper. Schools are no longer the institutions that push the boundaries of what is possible (they can no longer keep up)... that’s going to happen at your workplace

Brandon Hays

item.title: The scientific method
item.description:
Look, the goal is to prove I'm wrong. That means I win. I've proved I was stupid about something so that I can move on to being stupid about something more interesting.

Danielle Sucher, The Debugging Mindset, Ruby Rogues #150

item.title: Oculus VR
item.description:
Whew! They're blaming Neal Stephenson.

William Gibson

item.title: Success
item.description:
SHIP IT

(comments)

item.title: Wetware as a Service
item.description:
A lot of applications require straight up manual effort... This is what has stimulated some chunk of the SaaS industry. And what's really ironic is that what they're providing is not software.

Petar Maymounkov

item.title: Good clients
item.description:
If you find a good client, you treat him or her like a combination of the Pope, the Queen, and the Dalai Lama

chromatic
